Hodge theory and Hopf invariant one

Feb 12, 2019

Let be a Noetherian and separated Deligne-Mumford stack along with a flat and affine map , and let denote the moduli stack of formal groups along with a chosen coordinate up to degree . Then, there is some such that the pullback is affine. Indeed, we know that , where is the Lazard ring, so is affine because the morphism is affine. By Lemma 07SQ of the Stacks project, it suffices to prove that there is some for which is an algebraic space. Each is a Deligne-Mumford stack, and since a Deligne-Mumford stack is an algebraic space if and only if its diagonal is a closed embedding, we can conclude by using Theorem 8.10.5 of EGA IV(!) to conclude that the diagonal of some must be a closed embedding.

We know that the stack associated to the Thom spectrum (i.e, the stack associated to the Hopf algebroid ) is the stack . Suppose that the morphism admits an even-periodic refinement to an even-periodic Deligne-Mumford stack . Let . Since the morphism is affine, we know that is the stack associated to (see Theorem 4 of this document). It follows that the stack associated to is the stack . Since this is affine for some , we conclude that there is some for which is complex-oriented.

Let us explore the situation in a concrete example. Let be the classifying stack . This classifies algebraic tori, i.e., algebraic groups which become isomorphic to after a faithfully flat extension. There is a map sending a group to its completion at the identity component. Moreover, this morphism is affine. This is equivalent to the claim that the stack is affine. The moduli problem that this stack classifies is algebraic tori along with a coordinate; if is a map of tori which induces the identity on its completion (up to order three), then is the identity. It follows that there are no nontrivial automorphisms in the moduli problem, so is affine, as desired. In fact, this shows that is affine.

The morphism admits an even-periodic refinement to a stack , and . We therefore learn that is affine. The spectrum isn’t very interesting when localized at primes bigger than , so we will now localize at the prime . Then, is also known as ; this is the free -ring with a (chosen) nullhomotopy of (this is true even before -localization). In particular, is the free --algebra with a nullhomotopy of . (Note that is actually an -ring: it is the Thom spectrum of a bundle over , and this deloops twice to ; moreover, the map is an -ring map.)

What is a nullhomotopy of in a ring spectrum ? It’s a choice of factorization of the unit through the -cell complex . Assume that is even-periodic and complex oriented, and let denote the associated formal group. Then . The cofiber sequence gives an exact sequence of vector bundles on :

In general, one can construct such an exact sequence for an even-periodic refinement of a non-affine Deligne-Mumford stack (like ), and one obtains a similar extension as an element of , where is again the “Lie algebra” sheaf on . The choice of a nullhomotopy of is then equivalent to the data of a splitting of this exact sequence. The space of such splittings is . This is the algebraic analogue of the fact that parametrizes nullhomotopies of .

Since is not nullhomotopic in , the element of classifying is nontrivial. Then, one can use the above discussion to observe that is the universal stack (scheme) over with a chosen trivialization of this exact sequence. We conclude that the moduli problem associated to classifies algebraic tori along with a chosen splitting of the exact sequence (which corresponds to a chosen global section of ).

This could’ve also been deduced by looking at the definition of a coordinate up to degree , but there’s a reason we went through all of this effort: it helps us generalize to higher heights. The next most manageable and interesting case is . In this case, is the moduli stack of smooth elliptic curves, and the morphism is again affine. We conclude that there is some such that is affine. In fact, one can show that works. If we localize at the prime , then works, so (we will now -localize) is complex oriented. The spectrum splits up (since we -localized) into a wedge of homotopy commutative ring spectra denoted , in much the same way as splits up into a wedge of copies of . The spectrum is the free -ring with a chosen nullhomotopy of , and is complex oriented.

Let us analyze the moduli problem associated to in the same way as we did for . The element is nonzero in . If denotes the universal elliptic curve over , then denoting , we have an exact sequence

where is the sheaf on whose global sections is . This exact sequence is an element of detecting .

The exact sequence is familiar to arithmetic geometers: it’s almost exactly the Hodge-de Rham exact sequence! If denotes the de Rham cohomology of (really, regarded as a sheaf on ), then there is an exact sequence

where we’ve implicitly used Serre duality above. (Note that is the Dieudonne module of the -divisible group over .) Both exact sequences and lie inside . This can be directly computed: it is exactly . Since both exact sequences are nontrivial, we conclude that they are either equal (in which case ) or one is twice the other (under the Baer sum). In any case, we find that choosing a nullhomotopy of in a -algebra is equivalent to choosing a splitting of the Hodge-de Rham exact sequence. In particular, the moduli problem associated to classifies elliptic curves along with a chosen splitting of the Hodge-de Rham exact sequence. More generally, one could replace with any -ring obtained as the global sections of a sheaf of -rings on an even-periodic refinement of a formally etale map from a Noetherian and separated Deligne-Mumford stack classifying a -divisible group of height .

It would be very interesting to generalize these observations to higher heights, since is detected at height .
